title: Chapter 1: Introduction
description: Key Terms, History, and Review Questions

cards.definition: professional organization representing psychologists in the United States

cards.term: professional organization representing psychologists in the United States

cards.definition: focus on observing and controlling behavior

cards.term: focus on observing and controlling behavior

cards.definition: study of how biology influences behavior

cards.term: study of how biology influences behavior

cards.definition: perspective that asserts that biology, psychology, and social factors interact to determine an individual's health

cards.term: perspective that asserts that biology, psychology, and social factors interact to determine an individual's health

cards.definition: area of psychology that focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders and other problematic patterns of behavior

cards.term: area of psychology that focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders and other problematic patterns of behavior

cards.definition: study of cognitions, or thoughts, and their relationship to experiences and actions

cards.term: study of cognitions, or thoughts, and their relationship to experiences and actions

cards.definition: area of psychology that focuses on improving emotional, social, vocational, and other aspects of the lives of psychologically healthy individuals

cards.term: area of psychology that focuses on improving emotional, social, vocational, and other aspects of the lives of psychologically healthy individuals

cards.definition: scientific study of development across a lifespan

cards.term: scientific study of development across a lifespan

cards.definition: long research paper about research that was conducted as a part of the candidate's doctoral training

cards.term: long research paper about research that was conducted as a part of the candidate's doctoral training

cards.definition: method for acquiring knowledge based on observation, including experimentation, rather than a method based only on forms of logical argument or previous authorities

cards.term: method for acquiring knowledge based on observation, including experimentation, rather than a method based only on forms of logical argument or previous authorities

cards.definition: area of psychology that applies the science and practice of psychology to issues within and related to the justice system

cards.term: area of psychology that applies the science and practice of psychology to issues within and related to the justice system

cards.definition: focused on how mental activities helped an organism adapt to its environment

cards.term: focused on how mental activities helped an organism adapt to its environment

cards.definition: perspective within psychology that emphasizes the potential for good that is innate to all humans

cards.term: perspective within psychology that emphasizes the potential for good that is innate to all humans

cards.definition: process by which someone examines their own conscious experience in an attempt to break it into its component parts

cards.term: process by which someone examines their own conscious experience in an attempt to break it into its component parts

cards.definition: study of patterns of thoughts and behaviors that make each individual unique

cards.term: study of patterns of thoughts and behaviors that make each individual unique

cards.definition: consistent pattern of thought and behavior

cards.term: consistent pattern of thought and behavior

cards.definition: doctoral degree conferred in many disciplinary perspectives housed in a traditional college of liberal arts and sciences

cards.term: doctoral degree conferred in many disciplinary perspectives housed in a traditional college of liberal arts and sciences

cards.definition: allows young scientists to further develop their research programs and broaden their research skills under the supervision of other professionals in the field

cards.term: allows young scientists to further develop their research programs and broaden their research skills under the supervision of other professionals in the field

cards.definition: focus on the role of the unconscious in affecting conscious behavior

cards.term: focus on the role of the unconscious in affecting conscious behavior

cards.definition: scientific study of the mind and behavior

cards.term: scientific study of the mind and behavior

cards.definition: doctoral degree that places less emphasis on research-oriented skills and focuses more on application of psychological principles in the clinical context

cards.term: doctoral degree that places less emphasis on research-oriented skills and focuses more on application of psychological principles in the clinical context

cards.definition: area of psychology that focuses on the interactions between mental and emotional factors and physical performance in sports, exercise, and other activities

cards.term: area of psychology that focuses on the interactions between mental and emotional factors and physical performance in sports, exercise, and other activities

cards.definition: understanding the conscious experience through introspection

cards.term: understanding the conscious experience through introspection
Which of the following was mentioned as a skill to which psychology students would be exposed?
cards.definition: All of the above (critical thinking, use of the scientific method, critical evaluation of sources of information)

cards.term: All of the above (critical thinking, use of the scientific method, critical evaluation of sources of information)
cards.definition: Which of the following was mentioned as a skill to which psychology students would be exposed?

cards.term: Psyche is a Greek word meaning ________.

cards.definition: Psyche is a Greek word meaning ________.

cards.term: Before psychology became a recognized academic discipline, matters of the mind were undertaken by those in ________.

cards.definition: Before psychology became a recognized academic discipline, matters of the mind were undertaken by those in ________.

cards.term: In the scientific method, a hypothesis is a(n) ________.

cards.definition: In the scientific method, a hypothesis is a(n) ________.

cards.term: Based on your reading, which theorist would have been most likely to agree with this statement: Perceptual phenomena are best understood as a combination of their components?

cards.definition: Based on your reading, which theorist would have been most likely to agree with this statement: Perceptual phenomena are best understood as a combination of their components?

cards.term: ________ is most well-known for proposing his hierarchy of needs.

cards.definition: ________ is most well-known for proposing his hierarchy of needs.

cards.term: Rogers believed that providing genuineness, empathy, and ________ in the therapeutic environment for his clients was critical to their being able to deal with their problems.

cards.definition: Rogers believed that providing genuineness, empathy, and ________ in the therapeutic environment for his clients was critical to their being able to deal with their problems.

cards.term: The operant conditioning chamber (aka ________ box) is a device used to study the principles of operant conditioning.

cards.definition: The operant conditioning chamber (aka ________ box) is a device used to study the principles of operant conditioning.

cards.term: A researcher interested in how changes in the cells of the hippocampus (a structure in the brain related to learning and memory) are related to memory formation would be most likely to identify as a(n) ________ psychologist.

cards.definition: A researcher interested in how changes in the cells of the hippocampus (a structure in the brain related to learning and memory) are related to memory formation would be most likely to identify as a(n) ________ psychologist.

cards.term: An individual's consistent pattern of thought and behavior is known as a(n) ________.

cards.definition: An individual's consistent pattern of thought and behavior is known as a(n) ________.

cards.term: In Milgram's controversial study on obedience, nearly ________ of the participants were willing to administer what appeared to be lethal electrical shocks to another person because they were told to do so by an authority figure.

cards.definition: In Milgram's controversial study on obedience, nearly ________ of the participants were willing to administer what appeared to be lethal electrical shocks to another person because they were told to do so by an authority figure.

cards.term: A researcher interested in what factors make an employee best suited for a given job would most likely identify as a(n) ________ psychologist.

cards.definition: A researcher interested in what factors make an employee best suited for a given job would most likely identify as a(n) ________ psychologist.

cards.term: If someone wanted to become a psychology professor at a 4-year college, then s/he would probably need a ________ degree in psychology.

cards.definition: If someone wanted to become a psychology professor at a 4-year college, then s/he would probably need a ________ degree in psychology.

cards.term: The ________ degree in psychology places less emphasis on research and more emphasis on application of therapeutic skills.

cards.definition: The ________ degree in psychology places less emphasis on research and more emphasis on application of therapeutic skills.

cards.term: Which of the following degrees would be the minimum required to teach psychology courses in high school?

cards.definition: Which of the following degrees would be the minimum required to teach psychology courses in high school?

cards.term: One would need at least a(n) ________ degree to serve as a school psychologist.

cards.definition: One would need at least a(n) ________ degree to serve as a school psychologist.

The active application of a set of skills to information for the understanding and evaluation of that information. It involves maintaining an attitude of skepticism, recognizing internal biases, making use of logical thinking, asking appropriate questions, and making observations.

cards.term: The active application of a set of skills to information for the understanding and evaluation of that information. It involves maintaining an attitude of skepticism, recognizing internal biases, making use of logical thinking, asking appropriate questions, and making observations.

cards.definition: Translating to 'whole' or 'configuration', this perspective considers how different sensory perceptions are interpreted via a configuration. It emphasizes that the whole is different from the sum of its parts.

cards.term: Translating to 'whole' or 'configuration', this perspective considers how different sensory perceptions are interpreted via a configuration. It emphasizes that the whole is different from the sum of its parts.

cards.definition: A form of learning behavior studied by Pavlov where an organism learns to produce a reflex response to a stimulus that was previously neutral.

cards.term: A form of learning behavior studied by Pavlov where an organism learns to produce a reflex response to a stimulus that was previously neutral.

cards.definition: A psychologist whose focus on positive and negative reinforcement of learned behaviors (operant conditioning) had a lasting influence in psychology.

cards.term: A psychologist whose focus on positive and negative reinforcement of learned behaviors (operant conditioning) had a lasting influence in psychology.

cards.definition: First published in 1968, she stimulated a feminist revolution in psychology by critiquing the field as a science. She criticized male psychologists for constructing the psychology of women entirely out of their own cultural biases without experimental verification.

cards.term: First published in 1968, she stimulated a feminist revolution in psychology by critiquing the field as a science. She criticized male psychologists for constructing the psychology of women entirely out of their own cultural biases without experimental verification.

cards.definition: Famous African American researchers known for studies that were instrumental in the Brown v. Board of Education case. They studied the psychological effects of segregation on African American children.

cards.term: Famous African American researchers known for studies that were instrumental in the Brown v. Board of Education case. They studied the psychological effects of segregation on African American children.

cards.definition: A psychologist who made significant strides in the field, invented the paired-associate technique, and later became the first female president of the American Psychological Association.

cards.term: A psychologist who made significant strides in the field, invented the paired-associate technique, and later became the first female president of the American Psychological Association.

cards.definition: The first Latina to receive a doctorate in psychology in the U.S. She demonstrated the benefit of intervention to overcome conduct disorders and researched ethnic identity.

cards.term: The first Latina to receive a doctorate in psychology in the U.S. She demonstrated the benefit of intervention to overcome conduct disorders and researched ethnic identity.

cards.definition: The first African American woman to receive a PhD in psychology. She studied the impacts of educational segregation and isolation based on race.

cards.term: The first African American woman to receive a PhD in psychology. She studied the impacts of educational segregation and isolation based on race.

cards.definition: The study of how individuals interact and relate with others and how such interactions can affect behavior.

cards.term: The study of how individuals interact and relate with others and how such interactions can affect behavior.

cards.definition: A PhD puts more emphasis on research, while a PsyD (Doctor of Psychology) places less emphasis on research and more emphasis on the application of therapeutic skills.

cards.term: A PhD puts more emphasis on research, while a PsyD (Doctor of Psychology) places less emphasis on research and more emphasis on the application of therapeutic skills.
